title: 110_s514
content: The Act is titled the "Muscogee Nation of Florida Federal Recognition Act" and includes findings. The Muscogee Nation of Florida is comprised of lineal descendants of persons historically part of the Creek Confederacy, settling in north Florida panhandle in autonomous communities. After the dissolution of the Creek Confederacy, ancestors relocated and reestablished home sites, traditions, ceremonial centers, tribal government, and tribal economy in rural areas. Members of the Muscogee Nation of Florida have a strong ancestral connection, as some still reside on original home sites of their Creek ancestors. They have a historical participation in treaties and census records, demonstrating their longstanding presence and identity. In 1971, the Secretary of the Interior distributed per capita payments to members of the Muscogee Nation for land claim settlements. In 1978, the Florida Tribe of Eastern Creek Indians, now known as the Muscogee Nation of Florida, was established through an election held by the Northwest Florida Creek Indian Council. In 1986, the State of Florida recognized the Muscogee Nation. The State of Florida recognized the Muscogee Nation of Florida as an Indian tribe, with the community of Bruce serving as a governing center for over 150 years. The Nation utilized the Antioch Cemetery, maintained a school from 1895 to 1947, established a church in 1912, and had a ceremonial area on Bruce Creek until the late 1920s. The Muscogee Nation of Florida has a ceremonial area in Blountstown, Florida, where traditional events like Green Corn ceremonies are held. The community of Bruce is recognized as the tribal government center, and the Nation has received grants and contracts for providing services to its members in the past 30 years. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "member" refers to individuals enrolled in the Muscogee Nation of Florida. The term "Nation" refers to the Muscogee Nation of Florida. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Tribal Council" refers to the governing body of the Nation. SEC. 4. FEDERAL RECOGNITION. Federal recognition is extended to the Muscogee Nation of Florida, allowing them to receive all services and benefits provided by the Federal Government to federally recognized Indian tribes without regard to the existence of a reservation or the location of member residences. The Muscogee Nation of Florida is federally recognized, allowing them to receive services and benefits without the need for a reservation. Their service area includes the community of Bruce in Walton County, Florida, and an area in the state bordered by the Escambia River and the St. Marks River. The constitution and bylaws of the Muscogee Nation of Florida are based on the Tribal Council dated January 21, 2001. The Secretary can hold a referendum for adopting a new constitution and bylaws upon request. The Tribal Council represents the Nation and its members, can enter contracts with Federal agencies, administer programs, and designate a successor. The membership roll is determined based on established criteria by the Nation's ordinance.
